Author: Hardjedef
Socio-political Tags: Royal, Priestly, Theocratic, Scholarly, Legitimation, Normalization, Mystical / Initiatory
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Father Archetype, Initiator
Short Description: Also known as Djedefhor or Hordjedef, he was a prince of Egypt’s 4th Dynasty, the son of Pharaoh Khufu. His teachings focus on moral conduct, humility, and preparation for the afterlife. Over time, Hardjedef was revered and remembered not only as a royal figure but as a sage who accompanied Osiris into the underworld.

Author: Ptahhotep
Socio-political Tags: Administrative / Bureaucratic, Scribal, Scholarly, Normalization, Legitimation, Judicial
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Father Archetype, Persona, Initiator
Short Description: A vizier of Egypt’s 5th Dynasty, serving under Pharaoh Djedkare Isesi around 2400 BCE.He is best known as the author of the oldest and most complete Egyptian wisdom texts. His teachings emphasize humility, restraint, fairness, and the importance of listening, guiding officials and scribes in proper conduct.

Author: Kagemni
Socio-political Tags: Administrative / Bureaucratic, Scribal, Scholarly, Normalization, Legitimation
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Father Archetype, Persona, Initiator
Short Description: A high-ranking vizier serving as the chief official under a pharaoh, most often associated with Teti of the 6th Dynasty. His teachings became part of the scribal curriculum, shaping how young officials and elites were trained in conduct and ethics. Kagemni was remembered as one of Egypt’s great sages, alongside figures like Ptahhotep and Hardjedef.

Author: Amenemope
Socio-political Tags: Scribal, Scholarly, Normalization, Mystical / Initiatory, Legitimation
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Father Archetype, Initiator, Persona
Short Description: A scribe and sage who lived during the late New Kingdom. His teachings emphasize humility, honesty, patience, and inner peace, contrasting the fleeting value of wealth with the lasting value of virtue. The text is framed as a father’s advice to his son, continuing the Egyptian sebayt tradition of moral instruction. Amenemope is remembered as one of Egypt’s great wise men, whose ideas even show striking parallels with sections of the biblical Book of Proverbs.

Author: Shabaka
Socio-political Tags: Royal, Priestly, Theocratic, Imperial, Legitimization, Normalization, Mystical / Initiatory, Propagandistic
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Father Archetype, Initiator, Wise Old Man, Hero
Short Description: Shabaka was a pharaoh of Egypt’s 25th Dynasty, from the Kushite line of rulers who reigned around 716–702 BCE. He is remembered as both a royal restorer and a religious guardian, preserving Egypt’s sacred traditions through the Shabaka Stone and the Memphite Theology.

Author: Ankhsheshonqy
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Trickster, Shadow, Father Archetype
Short Description: A scribe active likely during the late Pharaonic to early Hellenistic period. Ankhsheshonqy was possibly imprisoned after becoming entangled in a political plot, and he composed his sayings while in jail. The maxims mix practical advice, moral lessons, and ironic warnings, often reflecting a more skeptical and worldly tone than earlier sebayt.
